author: Legal Correspondent
text:
Reacting to submissions by BJP MLAs in Arunachal Pradesh that a Governor’s official acts cannot be scrutinised threadbare by the judiciary, the Supreme Court on Thursday said the court could not be expected to watch quietly from the sidelines if “democracy is slaughtered.”

“If democracy is slaughtered, how can the court remain silent?” a Constitution Bench led by Justice J.S. Khehar asked senior advocate Shekhar Naphade, appearing for the MLAs.

The senior advocate submitted that the Governor was “duty bound to act” when he realised that he was being stonewalled.

Mr. Naphade argued that the Governor’s reports to the President were part of his constitutional compulsion to act in the face of adversity, and had he not done so, he was even liable to be removed under the Doctrine of Pleasure held by the President over his tenure.

The Bench summoned for the correspondence of the Arunachal Pradesh Assembly from last October to ascertain the circumstances which led to the Governor’s decision to advance the Assembly session from January 14, 2016 to December 16, 2015.
title: Can’t be mute if democracy is slaughtered: SC
